text:
Ro: Hey guys, welcome to another Nerdy Nummies!
Today I have my friend

Ro: Travis from NexGen, I’ll put his link
below so you can go check it out.

Ro: He is a world record over-clocker, which
is basically making computers

Ro: run really, really fast. Travis: Absolutely,
it’s trying to make the

Travis: computer run as fast as possible so
you can run the game at the highest
Travis: settings with the most frame rates.

Ro: Which is amazing, that they use liquid
nitrogen to do this.

Ro: To make your computer work super, super
fast.

Ro: Let’s start with the facts about liquid
nitrogen. It is super, super cold.

Travis: Absolutely, liquid nitrogen is 320
degrees below zero, therefore it is

Travis: extremely cold! And uh, in its state
while it’s a liquid, um, it does

Travis: get absorbed into clothing and it
can cause burns if it sits on

Travis: the skin too long, so what we are
gonna do is we’re gonna wear safety

Travis: glasses. Ro: Yeah, safety! Travis:
And we’re gonna have our gloves.

Travis: That way we’re protected, and uh,
while handling liquid nitrogen you always

Travis: want to be careful that you’re not
splashing it around.

Travis: In the event that liquid nitrogen does
come in contact with your skin,

Travis: there’s the leidenfrost effect,
which will actually prevent the liquid

Travis: nitrogen from coming in direct contact,
so it will bead up and simply

Travis: roll off the surface of your skin.
So long as your hand is dry and you

Travis: aren’t making a cup to try and capture
the liquid inside. You would

Travis: see that after it comes in contact
with the skin for a prolonged

Travis: amount of time it will start to cause
frost burn.

Ro: So you can actually stick your hand in
liquid nitrogen and pull it out,

Ro: but not hold it in there. Travis: Absolutely,
if it’s something quick,

Travis: it’s kind of like a game of hot
potato, you know you can splash it

Travis: on there a little bit and it’s just
going to simply roll off, you can

Travis: even kind of play around with it.
And see how it just kind of beads

Travis: up and moves around across the surface
of the table.

Ro: Today we’re gonna be making strawberry
vanilla ice cream with
Ro: liquid nitrogen! Let’s get started!

Ro: What you’ll need is: 2 cups of strawberries,
chopped up, 2 tablespoons of

Ro: vanilla, 1-1/2 cups of half and half,
4 cups of heavy cream,
Ro: 2 cups of sugar, and measuring spoons!

Travis: You’ll also need 1 larger stainless
steel mixing bowl, 1 stainless

Travis: steel wire whisk, and plenty of liquid
nitrogen!

Ro: We’re gonna mix all the ingredients
together, and then slowly pour in

Ro: all the liquid nitrogen. And then, a cup and
a half of half and half.

Ro: And 4 cups of heavy whipping cream. We
did the math, we knew we had enough.

Ro: And a couple tablespoons of vanilla extract,
you can add as much as you

Ro: want. It depends how vanilla-y you want
your ice cream to taste!

Ro: I want it to taste very vanilla-y! There
we go!

Ro: Travis, you have actually made this, so
what do we do next?

Travis: Well, you’re gonna want to mix everything
together and try to get it all

Travis: dissolved before we put the liquid
nitrogen in, because we want

Travis: to have that ice cream consistency.
Ro: OK, so I take this whisk

Ro: and just mix it together, kind of like
cake batter! When you’re mixing

Ro: everything together? Travis: Absolutely.
Ro: OK, I’ve never made ice cream
Ro: before, this is my first time.

Travis: You’ll find that with liquid nitrogen
it’ll be the easiest way to

Travis: make ice cream. Ro: Is it? Travis:
Well, typically when you make

Travis: ice cream, it’s a process that lasts
several hours, with the liquid

Travis: nitrogen, we’re gonna speed that
process up, we’ll do it in a matter

Travis: of seconds to minutes. Ro: Hmmm. Travis:
When we use liquid nitrogen

Travis: it’s actually gonna freeze so fast
that the crystalline structure

Travis: will be very, very, very small, meaning
that the ice cream will be
Travis: extremely smooth and very delicious!

Travis: Go ahead and add those strawberries
now. Ro: OK!

Ro: I went a little crazy, I don’t know
if this is 2 cups of strawberries,
Ro: I just cut up so many of them.

Ro: And, that’s probably better… There
you go, get in there!

Ro: Yummy! Travis: As long as there isn’t
anything still at the bottom, like

Travis: maybe some residual sugar. Ro: Mmmhmm.
Travis: And you’ve got your

Travis: ingredients, like the strawberries,
mixed in properly, then you can

Travis: start to add the liquid nitrogen.
Ro: OK.

Travis: I’ll be doing the mixing. Ro: Yeah.
Travis: So I will give you the

Travis: honor of pouring the liquid nitrogen.
Ro: I like this idea!

Ro: This is a good idea, because he’s gonna
man-muscle it, while I just get
Ro: to pour the cool stuff!

Ro: Alright, I’ll slowly pour it, so just
tell me when, OK?

Travis: Just start to slowly pour it in there,
and as we see how much

Travis: it starts to stick together and freeze,
you can start to add more.

Travis: So go ahead and continue to give a
slow pour. Ro: Ah it looks so cool!
Ro: A-bubble, bubble, toil and trouble!

Travis: And you’ll start to see it bubble
up quite a bit here.

Ro: So when it’s bubbling, what is that
doing? It’s like boiling, but it’s

Ro: boiling cold? Travis: Yes, absolutely,
the liquid nitrogen itself is

Travis: boiling inside of the ice cream mix,
and as it boils it will create that

Travis: nitrogen gas that you see escaping.
So it’s gonna kind of foam up
Travis: the ice cream. And we can  go ahead and continue to add that liquid nitrogen

Travis: as we stir, and it’s becoming a
little bit heavy

Travis: as I try to mix this up. Ro: This
looks awesome!

Travis: It’s definitely forming into ice
cream right about now!
Ro: Yes! Stand back, I’m doing science!

Ro: Whoa, look at that! Amazing! The bowl
feels frosty!

Travis: We’ve got it frozen, it is, officially
ice cream!

Ro: Woo-hoo! It is ready to eat, check this
out!

Ro: We made vanilla ice cream with strawberries!
Yum-yum-yum-yum-yum!
Ro: It is ready to eat!

Ro: Can I touch it? Travis: Oh yeah, mmmm!
How’s that taste?

Ro: Oh my gosh, it’s actually really good!
Oh my gosh!
Ro: Maybe a little bit too much vanilla, but…
Travis: It’s triple vanilla, remember?

Ro: Got this cute little scoop, dee-dee! I’m
gonna scoop ‘em up, and it’s
Ro: ready to eat! Rewp!
Ro: I’m gonna have to… Oh there we go!
Ro: Oh! It’s so cute!

Ro: Da-da! All done! Thanks you guys for watching
this episode of Nerdy Nummies!

Ro: And thank you Travis for being here, this
was a lot of fun.

Travis: Thank you for having me on, it has
been an enormous amount of fun!

Ro: Yeah, I have never played with liquid
nitrogen before, or made ice cream,
Ro: so this was a first. We did good!

Ro: If you guys have any other suggestions

Ro: happen! OK, oop! Bye-bye!
